snippet: Suicides have increased among the military’s Special Operations forces, prompting concern that brain injuries and stress have not been properly treated. Susan Ullman’s husband, Sgt. First Class Michael B. Lube, committed suicide last summer.
abstract: Suicides have increased among the military’s Special Operations forces who served in Iraq or Afghanistan, prompting concern that significant traumatic brain injuries and post-traumatic stress disorder have not been properly treated; 49 members have killed themselves in past two and a half years, more than in preceding five years; senior commanders are openly pushing their troops to seek help.

byline.original: By THOM SHANKER and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr

lead_paragraph: Suicides have increased among the military’s Special Operations forces, prompting concern that brain injuries and stress have not been properly treated. Susan Ullman’s husband, Sgt. First Class Michael B. Lube, committed suicide last summer.

headline.main: War’s Elite Tough Guys, Hesitant to Seek Healing
headline.print_headline: War’s Elite Tough Guys, Hesitant to Seek Healing

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
